item.title: Safari Is Working On Native Lazy-Loading Images
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: This little Webkit gem is really nice to see: Bug 200764 – Main implementation for lazy image loading. Chrome recently started supporting native lazy-loading, being the first, and so far only browser to do so. This concept is such a good idea, it would be a shame for it to remain Chrome only. Having it […]
item.content:encoded:
This little Webkit gem is really nice to see: Bug 200764 – Main implementation for lazy image loading.

Chrome recently started supporting native lazy-loading, being the first, and so far only browser to do so. This concept is such a good idea, it would be a shame for it to remain Chrome only. Having it show up in a future version of Safari would be awesome.

I found two Mozilla bugs filed regarding lazy loading support, 1542784 and 947427. Unfortunately there hasn’t been any movement on either one.

item.title: Opera Browser Switching to WebKit
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: Today it was announced that the Opera web browser will be switching to WebKit. It still amazes me that WebKit has done so well. It basically owns the modern mobile device browser market, via Android and iOS. Ten years ago when WebKit was first announced as part of the initial Safari launch I would not have […]
item.content:encoded:
Today it was announced that the Opera web browser will be switching to WebKit.  It still amazes me that WebKit has done so well.  It basically owns the modern mobile device browser market, via Android and iOS.  Ten years ago when WebKit was first announced as part of the initial Safari launch I would not have guessed that it would go on to be so popular.

Other posts about the Opera transition to WebKit worth reading are WebKit is the jQuery of Browser Engines by John Resig and Opera and WebKit: a personal perspective by Bruce Lawson ( who wrote the Opera announcement too ).

On top of that the report on the activity of companies in the WebKit project was really interesting.  There are fair number of different companies contributing to WebKit now, though not too surprising that Apple and Google are the two biggest groups currently.  I’d expect to see the Opera folks take up a strong third position on that list in the next year or two.

item.title: PhantomJS: Headless WebKit with JavaScript API
item.dc:creator: josephscott
item.description: PhantomJS: Headless WebKit with JavaScript API. The rendering example looks promising for capturing screenshots of URLs.
item.content:encoded: PhantomJS: Headless WebKit with JavaScript API. The rendering example looks promising for capturing screenshots of URLs.
